summary:
Infratil Limited - CDC Independent Valuation (30 June 2025) - Material Information Summary

  • Valuation Increase: Infratil’s 49.76% stake in CDC increased by A$148M (midpoint: A$6.75B vs. A$6.60B in March 2025).
  • Equity Valuation Decline: CDC’s 100% equity value decreased 1% to A$13.56B (from A$13.70B), driven by higher assumed interest costs.
  • Capital Deployment: Infratil acquired an additional 1.58% stake for A$220M, increasing ownership to 49.76%. Further A$250M commitment expected within 12 months.
  • Operational Update:
  • Added 54MW operational capacity (Auckland), total operational capacity now 372MW.
  • Under construction: 453MW (up from 382MW), including expansions in Melbourne (+105MW) and Canberra (+19MW).
  • Valuation Methodology Shift: Primary method changed to DCF (from Historical Transaction), with unchanged cost of equity (11.05%) and terminal growth (2.5%).

Omitted: Regional breakdowns, minor assumption adjustments, and non-material pipeline details.

Summary of Material Information:

  • Gas Supply Agreement: Contact Energy signs 7-year deal with GGNZ Ltd for up to 7PJ/year of gas supply (effective 1 October 2025), with a 3-year extension option from 2032.
  • Strategic Impact: Diversifies gas supply, reduces reliance on single field, supports retail gas customers and peaking generation.
  • Renewable Transition: Expected 200–300GWh/year of gas-fired generation (peaking units), supporting 98% renewable output (post-Taranaki CC closure in late 2025).
  • Investment Context: Part of >$2B committed in renewable projects over past 4 years; net zero generation target by 2035.

No direct trading/capital markets action required.

• Director Share Purchase: Hartley Campbell Atkinson (Director of AFT Pharmaceuticals) acquired 200,000 ordinary shares at an average price of NZD $2.83 per share (~NZD $566,000 total).
  • Post-Transaction Holdings: Total holding via the Atkinson Family Trust increased to 72,259,496 shares (from 72,059,496). Direct beneficial ownership: 867,826 shares.
  • Transaction Dates: On-market purchases executed on 30 Jun, 1 Jul, and 2 Jul 2025.

No material impact on capital structure or liquidity identified. Disclosure reflects routine director trading.

Material Information Summary – Air New Zealand (ASX) – Monthly Traffic & Media Updates

Key Operational Metrics (May 2025 vs. Prior Year)

  • Capacity Reduction: Group ASKs down 2.7% (Long Haul: -2.2%, Domestic: -5.5%, Short Haul Int’l: -2.2%) due to engine maintenance delays.
  • Load Factor Improvement: Group PLF up 2.5 pts to 82.0% (YTD: +1.9 pts to 83.5%).
  • Revenue Strength: YTD underlying RASK up 2.0% (Long Haul: +2.8%, Short Haul: +0.4%).
  • Asia Outperforms: Passenger growth to Asia up 5.0% (May), 8.0% YTD; RASK up 4.8 pts for May.

Media Releases (Material Impact Highlights)

  1. Tasman/Pacific Expansion: 1.7M seats added (Oct 2025–Mar 2026), with 130K extra seats (+8% premium) and 42 weekly widebody flights.
  2. China Tourism Partnership: Joint $500K NZD marketing push with Air China to boost inbound travel; 33% premium seat increase on Shanghai–Auckland route.
  3. North America Capacity: 34K additional seats (Oct–Mar), including 20.5K premium seats (+15% YoY); 787 retrofits for enhanced cabins.
  4. New Routes/Domestic Boost:
  5. Christchurch–Adelaide (seasonal, 15K seats from Oct 2025).
  6. 36K extra domestic seats (Auckland–South Island routes, winter 2025).
  7. Fleet Expansion: Two new A321neos (214 seats each) to add 70K annual seats; first entered service June 2025.

No Material Information Identified:

  • Capital structure changes, dividends, or liquidity updates.

Brevity Note: Excluded routine director quotes, FX impacts, and non-material regional stats. Focused on capacity, revenue drivers, and network changes impacting demand/costs.

Summary tailored for trading/capital decisions: Prioritizes operational trends, revenue metrics, and growth initiatives.

THL Updated FY25 Guidance Summary:

  • FY25 uNPAT guidance: Expected at lower end of analyst range ($27.0M–$34.4M), weighed by weak global RV sales and softer USA market.
  • Manufacturing divisions (AU/NZ): Earnings decline due to reduced production volumes and inventory adjustments.
  • FY26 outlook:
  • Net debt: ~$500M (ex-IFRS 16 leases).
  • Forward rental revenue growth: Double-digit % in AU/NZ (25% ahead of prior year); USA bookings recovering post-Liberation Day decline (single-digit % drop YoY).
  • Potential impairments: Goodwill (NZ$36M, USA business) under review; other non-cash items may impact statutory NPAT (no covenant impact).

Materially negative: Earnings pressure, potential impairment, and cyclical challenges highlighted.
